DataElement.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Radiography Evidence Brain Metastasis External Hippocampus Present Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The Yes/No indicator related to the presence of brain metastases outside 5 mm margin around either hippocampus visible on a CT or MRI prior to surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Radiography Evidence Brain Metastasis External Hippocampus Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the presence of brain metastases outside 5 mm margin around either hippocampus visible on a CT or MRI prior to surgery.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995)

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

Property.preferredName: Radiography Evidence Brain Metastasis External Hippocampus Present
Property.preferredDefinition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.:Knowledge on which to base belief.:An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.:The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.:Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.:A curved gray matter structure of the temporal lobe lying on the floor of the lateral ventricle of the brain.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.
Knowledge on which to base belief.
An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.
A curved gray matter structure of the temporal lobe lying on the floor of the lateral ventricle of the brain.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.
